page.title: 17Egg Production in Fenton
page.content: There is a small poultry farm run as a family business employing three of the family, three full-time male and eight part-time female workers. Eggs are produced from a flock of 60,000 hens by factory farming methods. 10,000 birds are housed in cages in six sheds and are automatically fed, watered and cleaned. Point of lay pullets are bought in at 12 weeks, start laying at 16 weeks and work to a peak of 10,000 eggs per day. The hens are kept for approximately 18 months, then sold for human consumption or pet food. Some eggs are graded and sold locally; the majority are sent to an Egg Packing Station to be graded and packed for sale to supermarkets and shops. A smaller farm is run on similar lines by another family. Some of their eggs are sent to the Packing Station but most are sold, ungraded, at the door.
